pullRequest.body:
This PR uses Arzela-Ascoli to prove local compactness of the Pontryagin dual.

---

nodes.body: I'm marking this as awaiting-review in case a lemma other than #12002 would be better for this situation.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#11334~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#6844~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#12002~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

### PR summary [54c5e4f42e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/11335/commits/54c5e4f42e9586d37439ed05f20f4e64565f8612)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.PontryaginDual | 1260 | 1347 | +87 (+6.90%) |
| Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.ContinuousMonoidHom | 1061 | 1074 | +13 (+1.23%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.ContinuousMonoidHom`|13|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.PontryaginDual`|87|

</details>

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ instance [LocallyCompactSpace G] : LocallyCompactSpace (PontryaginDual G) := by`
`+ locallyCompactSpace_of_equicontinuousAt`
`+ locallyCompactSpace_of_hasBasis`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

I haven't checked carefully whether these proofs can be significantly simplified, but I don't think it's too big a problem even if they can be. 

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by j-loreaux.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10036395196/job/27734062060)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10036395196/job/27734062608)
Fingers crossed, but I think it's possible there is a big simplification available here in the case of `FirstCountableTopology X`.

Is there a reason this doesn't work? (I mean, I understand it's not really associated to the Pontryagin Dual, but :shrug:)
```suggestion
@[to_additive]
theorem locallyCompactSpace_of_equicontinuousAt (U : Set X) (V : Set Y)
```

How related is this to [TopologicalGroup.exists_antitone_basis_nhds_one](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Group/Basic.html#TopologicalGroup.exists_antitone_basis_nhds_one)? I'm just wondering if it's possible to get away with a more natural condition here at all like `FirstCountableTopology`. The answer is likely no, but I thought I'd ask.

Yeah, I think I thought about this possibility, but the condition in docs#TopologicalGroup.exists_antitone_basis_nhds_one isn't enough to get the condition in `hV` (For instance, think about the circle where the first neighborhood is the whole circle and the second neighborhood is the right half of the circle. This satisfies the condition in docs#TopologicalGroup.exists_antitone_basis_nhds_one but not the condition in `hV`). And I think you need a condition like `hV` in order to prove equicontinuity.
Can you prove `hV` from first countability (even without using the existing result)? It just feels like these are somehow very closely connected to me.

Hmm, I had thought not, but now I'm not so sure. I guess if you take V(n+1) = Vn cap sq^(-1) (Vn), then this has the property that x in Vn and x^2 in Vn implies x in V(n+1). And you can probably further intersect with the (n+1)st term of an existing countable basis to finish the job?
Ah, the issue is that if you shrink V(n+1) then hV no longer holds. And I wasn't able to find a way around this.
Without some more clever way of modifying the sequence, you would need to find a V0 such that iterating V(n+1) = Vn cap sq^(-1) (Vn) gives a basis.
Fair enough. That makes sense. It seemed too good to expect. I didn't see a way to do it either.
